page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. to be advertised, that yo
r
letter by
Persivall
of
e 25 of Sep
t
came to my
handes but yesterday, whiche is more then a moneth,
sins it was written. The mater of
Groninghen
was never otherwise by him, but in generall termes,
imparted unto me: and w
t
out any mention of
those gentlemen of
Frise,
that sette him a Worke:
whose names if I had knowen, as it is an exploit
that requireth expedition, so I would have sought
e meanes, before this time, to have knowen both
e
q
a
litie of
e persons, and also their credit, w
t
other
suche requisit pointes, as concerne a mater of that
moment. For there are numbers in these contreis
that endevo
r
an innovation of
e state, uppon pre-
tences of being devoted to her
Ma
tie
wheras it is ap-
parant in
a
great many, that it rather proceedeth
of their privat desire to be revenged uppon their
statesmen, then of any extraordinary zele to
e
common cause against
e Enemie: But what
course may best be taken, for furthering
e motion
of Groninghen, I will so consider as yo
r
H. hath
written, and walke so warely, as I trust her Ma
tie
wilbe pleased w
t
my doinges. In
e meane sea-
son, as yo
r
H. hath written, so I have persuaded
still w
t
those, w
t
whome I have dealt,
at her Ma
tie
in regard of her manifold burdens otherwise, will
not enter into any charge about this enterprise.
If
Count Hollocke
have any suche intelligence w
t
those of Groninghen, as her Hig
nes
is informed, it
hath bin caried so secretly,
at I have not heard
it reported. Howbeit there is likelihood of it
for
at he sojourned in
Embden,
and perhaps had
conference w
t
those that imparted it to me: w
ch
I suppose his letters to her Ma
tie
will signifie. The
matche between him and
e
Countesse of Bueren
is generally said to be concluded.
fol.117v
Yo
r
H. meaning about
e townes of
Holland,
at
have made some secret offer to her Ma
tie
, I doe
not well conceave, for
at no letter of mine, hath
made suche motion, nether hath any man heere
imaparted suche mater unto me. For I have al-
waies, to my Uttermost, dissuaded
at course, as-
well for
at it will breede an example of daun-
gerous consequence, as because I see so litle trust
to be reposed, in any of all
e promises of these
discontented persons. By Persivall and some
others I have often heard,
at those of Frise were
purposed to make an offer of
e Soveraignetie
of their Province, Unto her Ma
tie
. But in truth I
could never perceave,
at there was (some fewe
particular persons excepted) any suche incli-
nation in
e chiefest of
e state. For mine owne
part I have alwaies laboured to waine as
many from
at conceat, as by way of communi-
cation I have found addicted unto it. And
I doe it
e rather, for
at I was never yet in a
better hope of a good correspondence, between
these contreis
and her Ma
ties
people, then I am
at this present.
What my care hath bin in
at
behalf, and what meanes and speeches I have
used to
e
Councell
heere, to
Count Maurice
,
to
e rest of
e Countes, and likewise to those
Inglishe captaines, that have bin imploied in these
late services, and what courteous intertenment
hath ensued uppon it, both towardes
S
r
Francis
Vere
, and all
e Inglishe Captaines and souldiers,
and howe
e good liking of all handes hath conti-
nued ever since, I take no pleasure to report
my self, but this councell doth affourd me many
thankes, and S
r
Francis Vere is a witnes,
at w
t
out
my speciall endevo
rs
in divers respectes, the state
of these contreis had bin farre other then it is.
fol.115r
Whiche I am
e more willing at this p
nt
, to cause
in some sort to be knowen to yo
r
H. to
e end yo
w
might stand full assured,
at I am alwaies
an Enemie to all suche practises, as tend di-
rectly or indirectly, to
e breache of
e union
between her Ma
tie
and this people.
It is accorded by
e
states of Holland
,
at
e
Inglishe foote companies w
t
S
r
Francis Vere, shall be
disposed in Garrison, in
Dordrecht,
Roterodame,
Delf,
and other of
e best townes of Holland.
And in lieu of those bandes that were drawen
fourth of
Flushing
and
ostend
by squadrons, w
ch
are all returned, they desire, and to that effect
have written to
e Governo
rs
of those townes,
at
there may from eche towne an entier company be
sent hither. The late controversy
risen between
e townes of North Holland is ac-
corded by mediation of
e states and Count
Maurice. Likewise
e mutinie of
Lief-
kens Hoecke
is q
a
lified by those of
Zeland
w
t
certaine monethes pay, and other smalle con-
tentments. Whiche kinde of good usage hath
provoked a great part of
e soul
dier
s in
Lillo,
to
e like alteration, intending to have slaine
their Governo
r
and other officers. But their
purpose was discovered to
e Governo
r
, and
the chief Conspirato
rs
apprehended uppon it.
In effect there is a generall discontentment
growen in all
e Garrisons of Zeland, by
reason of their pay, whiche I thinke Count
Maurice, will goe in person and endevo
r
to
appeare. The souldiers of
Schinckes
sconce are become so mutinous, that
we are almost out of all hope,
at they will
be reclamed. Whereof their accustomed slacknes
fol.118v
in this place, hath bin a principall occasion. For
had they sent at
e first 400
li
sterling, all had
bin satisfied: wheras nowe they demaund their
full count and reckning: whiche is not thought
to be so litle as 6000
li
. Howbeit it is resolved
heere, that for avoiding
e perill and consequence
of suche compositions, they will yeld to no more
but 2 monethes pay for
e present, intending ra-
ther to forgoe
e Fort: and the offer therof they have
c
o
mitted to certaine fitte persons, whome they have
instructed w
t
all convenient persuasion to drawe
them from this disloialtie. It is knowen
at
e
Councell of
Cleve
doth practise in secret, to buy
e place for themselves, whiche many men doubt
ei
will obtene, for
at
e chiefest part of
e souldiers
doth consist of Clevelanders.
Count
William
of Frise hath wonne of late, by assault from
the Enemie, a Fort called
Saltcamp,
in
e territory
of Groninghen, at
e very entrance of Groninghen
Deepe, overagainst
Opslacke,
a place of speciall
importance, whereby
e passage of victuall to
e towne of Groninghen, is very muche hindred.
Which I thinke will be a helpe, for perfourmance
of
e enterprise afore mentioned. There
is no man yet named to
e Government of
Utrecht,
but most men are persuaded,
at it wilbe c
o
ferred
uppon Count Maurice: and thereof, me thinkes, there
is a c
o
mon good liking. The
Enemies forces,
at lay about
Bercke,
are said to be
departed, and gone to winter in
e Duchie of
Juliers,
where
e bruite goeth
at both
ei spoile
the contrey, whiche is very fertile, and are in
many divisions among themselves. Uppon their
departure
Cou nt Overstein
and
e Baron of
Pot-
lits
have conducted
into Bercke
130 cartes loaden w
t
victuall
and other necessaries, whereby the towne is provided
for a long time.
fol.119r
At this very instant, there came a good frinde
of purpose unto me, to advertise
e same that
yo
r
H hath written astouching Count Hollocke.
And likewise I finde by enquirie,
at
Joost
Van Cleve
of Embden, whose letter unto me I
sent inclosed w
t
my last, is familiarly ac-
quainted w
t
e Count: whereby there is likeli-
hood,
at
e ouverture of
e enterprise was made
at Embden unto him. But I am fully per-
suaded
at
e states of these contreis will utterly
dislike
at he should be imploied in that Action,
fearing, if he could worke unto himself
e gover-
ment of
e place, it may come so passe, that
ei
shall be worse neighboured afterward, then they
are at this present. I am pur-
posed to take
e next and
e fittest opportunitie,
to breake
is mater w
t
some of this Councell, lest
if it come otherwise to their knowledge, it may,
by wrong relation, be construed amisse, and give
occasion to suspicious humo
rs
of a newe discon-
tentment.
And so I take my humble leave
From
e Hage Oc
t
30.
8
9
Yo
r
H. most humbly bound Tho. Bodley
The newes are nowe come hither, that
e
Enemie is returned to
Rees,
but for
w
at
exploit, there is yet no speeche.
O
r
Deputies are newly arrived, and I
have receaved yo
r
H. letter of
e 15
W
t
my
LL.
Apostills to
e Deputies demaundes:
and also advertisment of my
L. of Buckhurst
comming,
who no dout, if he had come hither, upp
o
her Ma
ties
first resoluc
o
n, considering to w
at
daunger and
weaknes
e whole state was then reduced,
might have effected many thinges to her
Ma
ties
contentment. My only feare is nowe,
they will only urge
e redresse of that
w
ch
is amisse in her Ma
ties
people, and
yeld to very litle for
e reformac
o
n
of their owne government.
